title: Johnny Quigley
text:
John Quigley (28 June 1935 – 30 November 2004) born in the Govan area of Glasgow he was a Scottish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> and coach. His career peaked when he won the <a href="1959%20FA%20Cup%20Final">1959 FA Cup Final</a> with <a href="Nottingham%20Forest">Nottingham Forest</a>.
Playing career.
Celtic.
He began his career as a provisional signing with <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>, who farmed him out to <a href="Scottish%20Junior%20Football%20Association">Scottish Junior Football</a> club <a href="St%20Anthony%27s%20F.C.">St Anthony's</a>. After Celtic terminated his contract he joined another junior club, <a href="Ashfield%20F.C.">Ashfield</a>.
Nottingham Forest.
He was almost immediately signed by <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> in July 1957. He scored 58 goals in 270 appearances in the 7 seasons he was there.
In 1958 against <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a> he was the first Forest player to score a First Division post-war hat trick. His goal against <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> at <a href="Hillsborough%20Stadium">Hillsborough</a> won that <a href="1958-59%20FA%20Cup">1958-59 FA Cup</a> semi final. Forest were 2-0 up after 14 minutes. <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> hit back midway through the second half after Forest's opening goalscorer <a href="Roy%20Dwight">Roy Dwight</a> broke his leg in the 33rd minute. Forest had further personnel issue when cramp reduced <a href="Bill%20Whare">Bill Whare</a> to little more than a hobbling spectator. Quigley helped Forest protect their 2-1 lead to lift the trophy at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley</a>. He left Nottingham Forest in February 1965.
Huddersfield Town and Bristol City.
At <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a> he scored 5 goals in 68 appearances. In October 1966 he joined <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a> where he made 66 appearances and scored 7 goals.
Mansfield Town.
He moved to <a href="Mansfield%20Town%20F.C.">Mansfield Town</a> in July 1968 for <a href="Pound%20sterling">£</a>3,000. There Quigley was to enjoy the club's arguably most famous moment when they beat <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a> 3-0 in the <a href="1968-69%20FA%20Cup">1968-69 FA Cup</a>. West Ham's line up contained many of <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England's</a> <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> heroes. Mansfield progressed to the quarter final stage where they eventually lost to <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a>. He made 104 appearances and scored 2 goals and also captained the side.
Overall in his professional career he made 508 appearances and scored 72 goals.
Coaching career.
He branched into coaching at Mansfield. He became assistant player-manager/trainer-coach at <a href="Field%20Mill">Field Mill</a>.
In 1970 he went on to coach at <a href="Doncaster%20Rovers%20F.C.">Doncaster Rovers</a> including a spell as caretaker manager from November 1974 to February 1975. He remained as first team coach at Rovers until 1977, and later coached in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> in <a href="Kuwait">Kuwait</a> and <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> for five years.
Honours.
